Course.Name: Applied Statistics
Course.Description: This course concerns itself with probabilistic models, regression analysis, nonparametric statistics, and the basics of experimental design. Computer laboratory experience will be an important part of the course.

ABET-outcomes.item: (a) An ability to apply knowledge of computing and mathematics appropriate to the program's student outcomes and to the discipline.
(b) An ability to analyze a problem, and identify and define the computing requirements appropriate to its solution.
(i) An ability to use current techniques, skills, and tools necesary for computing practice.

(j) An ability to apply mathematical foundations, algorithmic principles, and computer science theory in the modeling and design of computer-based systems in a way that demonstrates comprehension of the tradeoffs involved in design choices.
(k) An ability to apply design and development principles in the construction of software systems of varifying complexity.

Learning-outcomes.item: Have the basic ideas regarding what is the difference between a population and a sample. be able to identify which is a representative sample and which is not
Be able to understand the difference between Statistics and Probability
Be able to represent given data through tables or pictures
Have the basic ideas of central tendencies and dispersions and will be able to use calculators to calculate them
Be able to get some heuristic ideas while looking at univariate and bivariate data and should be able to draw conclusions on the required parameters
Be able to calculate probabilities, moments etc. for various probability distributions (discrete or continuous).
Be able draw inferences related to studies involving one, two or more than two population means
Be able to draw inferences related to population variances
Be able to construct ANOVA tables and should have some basic ideas in experimental design
Have some basic ideas of correlation and linear regression
